column6: Nikolaos Kazantzis, Michael Timko, Andrew Teixeira
column8: Techno-Economic Analysis to Determine the Optimal Scale of Hydrothermal Liquefaction: Effects of Learning Rates, Transportation, and Technological Improvements.
column10: Due to the depletion of fossil fuel resources and the ubiquity of biomass feedstock worldwide, renewable fuel production pathways are at the forefront of energy research. Waste-to-energy conversion processes have the potential to displace incumbent fossil fuel usage. The focus of this study is to develop a techno-economic analysis (TEA) of hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) to determine the optimal scale of HTL plants under the effects of industry learning rates, delivery costs, and catalytic action. It was found that delivery costs dominate when feedstock is delivered due to its high volume relative to biocrude produced. These results indicate that HTL plants should predominantly be co-located with large feedstock sources.

column5: Olivia Caton, Marina Como, Jacqueline Cardin
column10: Pharmaceuticals are known to cause detrimental environmental effects including the increase of antibiotic resistant bacteria and development issues in animals, but research is still limited. This study aims to observe the effect current wastewater treatment methods have on three pharmaceuticals (SMZ, azithromycin, and salicylic acid) by analyzing their concentrations after seven treatment stages. Utilizing SPE and LC-MS, we determined the effluent concentrations of SMZ and azithromyicin were 81 ppb and 209 ppb, respectively, with similar concentrations appearing in surface water. This study did not observe a reduction in pharmaceutical concentration with current wastewater treatment methods, but noted their potential.

This project investigated several factors that may cause sticking within ceramic powder parts. Sticking between the die and powder has a highly detrimental effect during an automated manufacturing process. Powder residue could eventually ruin a part, thus stopping the entire process to fix the issue. Of the multitude of possible factors, several key ones were chosen for further study. These included the die temperature, the binder composition, and the number of parts created before cleaning the die. If changing these factors is significant enough, new standards for determining and preventing stickiness in the dies can be created, allowing for more complex parts, higher efficiency, and less rejection of defective parts, among other benefits.

column5: Nicole Bodinizzo, Donald Coley, Shayne Barton
column8: Revealing Surface Changes in Transparent Gallium Air Battery
column10: Gallium, a nontoxic liquid metal above 30C, demonstrates increased theoretical energy density which could perform better than commercial Li-ion batteries. For this study, a transparent cell was designed and constructed to visualize surface changes in gallium during redox cycles. As the first of its kind, the see-through cell helped us identify what happens at the failure point and why. By identifying these issues, our study aims to provide solutions that can bring gallium into commercial use.

column8: Best Practices for Adapting Manufacturing Documentation
column10: This projects compiles a set of best practices for adapting documentation in the manufacturing industry, and applies them to a real-world case. Through literary research and interviews with employees from Shell Catalysts, Frito-Lay, Rogers Corporation, and Waters Corporation, this report illustrates how many companies across the United States structure their documentation adaptation process, the common strengths and challenges they face, and the influence of federal regulations on their decisions. These trends, combined into a checklist and example template, were then applied to the adaptation of a Matisse SSOP for use at a Frito-Lay manufacturing plant.
